===Etymology===
This appellation comes from Imperial correspondence between the Chinese {{w|Sui Dynasty}} and Japan, and refers to the eastward position of Japan relative to China.

===Etymology 1===
{{ja-kanjitab|にち|k1=に|ほん|yomi=irr|sort=にほん}}

{{IPAchar|/nitipoɴ/}} → {{IPAchar|/nippoɴ/}} → {{IPAchar|/niɸoɴ/}} → {{IPAchar|/nihoɴ/}}

Coined in Japan of [[Sinic]] elements, as compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=にほん|日|tr1=nichi|t1=sun|本|tr2=hon|t2=origin}}. The ''hon'' element was apparently pronounced {{IPAchar|/poɴ/}} when first coined. Over time, the initial {{IPAchar|/p/}} [[lenition|lenited]], eventually becoming the {{IPAchar|/h/}} sound in modern Japanese.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

In older texts, this was read as [[訓読み#Japanese|kun'yomi]] as ''hi no moto''. The [[音読み#Japanese|on'yomi]] readings ''nippon'' and ''nihon'' became more common in the {{w|Heian period}}, with both persisting into modern use.<ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref> The ''nihon'' reading appears to be the most common in everyday Japanese usage.<ref>'''2012''', [http://www.nikkei.com/article/DGXBZO37629750Y1A221C1000000/ ニホンVSニッポン 「日本」の読み方、どっちが優勢?], [[w:The Nikkei|''The Nikkei'']]</ref>

===Etymology 3===
{{ja-kanjitab|じつ|k1=じっ|ほん|k2=ぽん|yomi=o}}
{{IPAchar|/zitpon/}} > {{IPAchar|/zippon/}} > {{IPAchar|/d͡ʑippon/}}

{{IPAchar|/zit͡ɕi, zit͡su/}} are the [[漢音#Japanese|kan'on]] readings of {{l|ja|日}}, as compared to the [[呉音#Japanese|goon]] reading {{IPAchar|/nit͡ɕi/}}.
